content.description: Mostly unmemorable climbing with the exception of a cool dyno near the start. Steep terrain yields to easier climbing pretty quickly.
content.location: See photo. This is the middle of 3 bolted routes on a small east-facing wall in a little corridor.

content.description: Strange route the has a cool traverse under the edge of the roof and then a weird move to turn the lip.

In my opinion, this is the standout route at Potter's Point (aside from the Caveman Boulder), and is also the easiest line here.

The climb starts up a shallow left-facing dihedral with some neat stemming/layback moves on a thin crack, then moves right along a horizontal break and up. Some loose flakes were encountered along the traverse.
content.protection: 5 or 6 bolts to 2 bolt anchor. Walkoff down the backside.
content.location: See photo. The route is marked by a dead leaning pine tree that parallels a pink colored face.

content.description: The route just to the right of caveman. It starts on a small boulder next to the wall where you can reach up and clip the first bolt from the ground. The start is as hard as it looks. Sustained hard moves end at the caveman anchor. The route is very well protected and can be toproped using a directional bolt found at the top.
content.location: The route is found at the caveman boulder located down and to the left of the entrance boulders. Stay to the left after you arrive at the first boulder at potters. Follow the rock cairns or bushwhack down to the back side of caveman. The bottom is accessed around the left side. Omega Glory is the 2nd route from the right, that heads up the steep face.

content.description: A fun climb up huge huecos, jugs, and edges on a near-vertical wall.
content.location: See photo. The right-most route on a small east-facing wall in a little corridor.

content.description: Route climbs up the right side of the large steep slabby face seen in the photo. I don't remember any specific cruxes, just good ol' fashion slabbin'.
content.protection: TR from 3 bolt anchor (2 are open shuts).
content.location: See photo. Scramble up to climber's right to access the anchors.

climbs.name: Caveman
climbs.fa: FTR Pat Holt, Warren Gibbs, and Bob Haas, 1987. Don't know FFA

content.description: Clamber up into the cave (easy 5th class), clip a bolt at the lip, grab some large huecos, then power into the very burly crux. Sustained climbing on beautiful rock awaits you above.
content.location: Right hand side of large cave. Heads straight up past large huecos and onto headwall of formation.

content.description: Route climbs the left side of the steep slabby face seen in the photo. A few tough pulls off the deck lead to more moderate climbing.
content.protection: TR from 3 bolt anchor (2 are open shuts).
content.location: See photo. Scramble up to climber's right to access the anchors.

content.description: I felt this line was a bit forced. Maybe 5.10c if you off-route the large block/ramp at the start that can practically get you to the second bolt. Anyways, a small left-leaning, left-facing corner marks the start of the route. Pull through the cruxy steep bulge onto easier ground above.
content.protection: 4 bolts to 2 bolt lower-off anchor (open shuts).
content.location: See photo. This is the left-most route on the small east-facing wall in a little corridor.
